text: How would you do something that only needs to happen at first start up?
I need to have a training data file. I supply it through assets. But I need to copy it to internal on first start up.
I could do this async in Application or in a dagger Module that belongs to the library that needs the training data.
I currently do it in MainActivity/Presenter with a flag in SharedPref but it feel extremely sloppy
Hm never I need to ask for Runtime permission first anyway.
Damn.
no secret here, you’re pretty much in the sharedprefs-flag land
haha - this is on the front page of /r/androiddev tho: <https://github.com/jonfinerty/Once>

attachments.title: jonfinerty/Once
attachments.text: Once - A small Android library to manage one-off operations.

text: I vouch for Once, it works great
who’s got a deep understanding of proguard here
I have a theory
if you have 2 versions of the same package, same version
and you run proguard on them
the classnames could theoretically mismatch, amirite?
theoretically, I’d say yeah
and if they mismatch, I could get a `> com.android.build.api.transform.TransformException: java.util.zip.ZipException: duplicate entry: com/google/android/gms/internal/zzacl.class`
unless proguard internally renames them the same
in the same project it shouldn't
since one is already mapped to X
<@U1PHH4DJ9|griname> has joined the channel
it applies the same behavior
nah, they are kinda the same project
but not quite
:confused:
wait how are you getting that
gradle should by itself see that you are importing different versions of the same package and use the newest one (in most cases)
they are the same version
different build
maybe not both apis are public and I could be saying too much
from your error i would be 90% sure that gradle doesn't understand that you are importing the same package twice
I have an idea
can you exclude it from gradle?
yes that
package options
hmmm
but that would make it not work innit
if you do this and you get another duplicate error, then you most certainly have a duplicate package
ok I’ll try that.
yes it won't work but the compilation step is what matters
at runtime it would blow up but if it blows up at compilation it's a good sign
ok so if that goes through
I’m going to have to find a way to package the entire play services with the repo
and somehow tell travis to pick that version.
last time I was getting such an error was because I was compiling autovalue and auto-parcel extension (which includes autovalue). What I needed to do was compile autovalue but `apt` autoparcel
again, same thing
ffs
:confused:
hi, anyone knows what does the line `multiDexEnabled true` do in gradle file?
it enables multidex building on your apk, meaning, it will output more then one .dex file for your application

text: <@U1PDT8ZKK>: nope
<@U09T8SFG8>: thanks
<@U1PK5URLJ|samuelh100> has joined the channel

Would a singleton be a good way to keep track of and query if the device has a working internet connection or not? as in a online/offline state. I would set it depending on if the request succeeded, and when i got the specific error that the request failed due to not having a working internet connection.
Most of the activities in the app needs to know this state
why not extend Application and add the listener there and, from the activities, add a listener to the listener of the application?
lol
That would work too, more work in my case, but might be worth it.
we had something similar - a broadcast receiver for connectivity
then an api to get current status, and subscribe for an update, when you get back online
perhaps a simple interface/listener approach would be cheaper instead of a broadcast
well if you need current connectivity status with updates then you need to use a broadcast
otherwise you’d need to poll it constantly
nvm,I missread your text
you’re right, add a broadcast receiver for the connectivity manager and on the activities, use a custom API to get that information from the application
I mean, I’m not constantly listening, just keeping track of if a request fail, and when a request first succeeds again.
so you’re talking about having connection to a specific endpoint instead of connectivity in general?

Well, kind of. Seem to only get so far checking for connectivity, 4g routers are often used, and seems like there is no problem connecting to them, but connecting to the internet itself is sometimes swing and miss.

Connection to an endpoint would mean some kind of “ping” to it while connectivity in general can be checked with ConnectivityManager (<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/net/ConnectivityManager.html>)
I mean I could ping first to decide if I should go through with the request, or treat the situation as if offline, but since I’m already doing the request..
From what I’ve seen, connectivityManager just checks if you are connected, not that it actually works.
Requests got a ping “baked in"
I had this pretty much thought out, but now I’m starting to question it :stuck_out_tongue:
I guess single instance does not have to be a singleton neither.

the thing with singletons is that, if used sparsely throughout the application, states can get out of control pretty easy. At first things go smooth, but as soon as the project starts to scale, youll have problems...
Oh, dumb me, I don’t need to know this at all. I just overcomplicated it :facepalm: sorry.
I can just go ahead as if offline when the request fail, I do the request anyway.
but you could easily prevent an unnecessary request by checking, with the ConnectivityManager if you have connectivity
a request has a timeout delay, you would just save time from the end user
Yeah, I should already be doing that I think, this is further down the process, but thanks for the help :slightly_smiling_face:
could you recommend some simple android architecture (probably MVP) guide/example? There is lot of them but they are mostly overengineered (imo)
ok weird shit
in OkHttp3 response
how the fck do I get the response URL?
cuz a 302 happens and I get a response from a different URL :confused:
and I need that URL
ok response.request().url()
naming is eh
but that is the original url from the request

shouldn’t be, it says:
"It may be the request generated in response to an HTTP redirect or authentication challenge. In this case the request URL may be different than the initial request URL."
so let’s hope that’s it
all right, sounds about right then
